description: Borrowed from French mascotte, from Occitan mascòta (“sortilege”), feminine diminutive of masca (“witch”), from Old Occitan masca, from Medieval Latin masca (“specter, nightmare”). More at mask.

entries.meaning: Something thought to bring good luck.
examples: I keep this red stone as a lucky mascot and always put it on my desk in exams.

entries.meaning: Something, especially a person or animal, used to symbolize a sports team, company, organization or other group.
examples: Tommy the Tyke is the mascot of Barnsley FC.

entries.meaning: (psychology) A personality type characterized by reliance on humor and positivity to wish away conflicts and attempt to defuse potentially violent situations.

verbs.description: mascot (third-person singular simple present mascots, present participle mascoting, simple past and past participle mascoted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To act as a mascot (for).
examples: The seniors were “mascoted” by two little girls dressed in green dresses  […]
